Authors:
Alex da Silva Corrêa, Andréa Brondani da Rocha, Sérgio
Ângelo Willani, Jéferson Mateus Dariva, Marcos Vinicios de Souza,
Marcelo Gravina de Moraes
Title:
YELLOW STUNT, A TOBACCO DISEASE CAUSED BY PYTHIUM
DISSOTOCUM.
Keywords:
Nicotiana tabacum, oomycete, soilborne disease, Internal
Transcribed Spacer
Abstract:
Yellow stunt is an emerging and very destructive disease
that affects tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum) in southern Brazil. The most
obvious disease symptoms are severe wilting, leaf yellowing, and
necrosis of roots and stem tissue close to the soil level. The objective
of this article is to identify the causal agent of tobacco yellow stunt.
Fifty six isolates were obtained from samples collected from stems and
roots of diseased tobacco plants and characterized at species level by
the analysis of the morphological data and the sequence of rDNA Internal
Transcribed Spacer regions 1 and 2 (ITS1 and ITS2). Mycelia of the
isolates were inoculated in pots with tobacco plants in a greenhouse.
Forty days after inoculation, plants were evaluated for the presence of
leaf and root symptoms. Although most of the isolates of different
species have caused wilting and root necrosis, only plants inoculated
with isolates from Pythium dissotocum have shown yellowing and stunting
symptoms like those observed in the diseased plants from the field.
Reisolated mycelium from roots inoculated with P. dissotocum has
produced the same reproductive structures in culture media as the field
collected isolates.
